headline: Ford Offers Its Employee Discount to All New Car Buyers
summary: Ford Motor is leaning into the tariff moment with a new ad campaign that highlights its American-made vehicles and extends its employee discounts to the wider buying public.  For its EVs, Ford is throwing in a home charger and free installation.  Employee discounts can shave several thousand dollars off the price of a new car or truck.

headline: Ford Offers New Buyer Discounts to Highlight Its Made-in-America Vehicles
summary: Ford Motor is leaning into the tariff moment with a new ad campaign that highlights its American-made vehicles and extends its employee discounts to the wider buying public.  The campaign, dubbed “From America, For America” starts Thursday and runs through June 2 on a range of 2024 and 2025 models, including those imported into the country.  For its EVs, Ford is also throwing in a home charger and free installation.

raw.headline: Ford Offers New Buyer Discounts to Highlight Its Made-in-America Vehicles

For its EVs, Ford is also throwing in a home charger and free installation.

headline: Tariffs Will Cost This Detroit Automaker Billions More Than Its Rival
summary: When it comes to U.S. auto company investors, the big question most want answered right now involves the potential impact on these companies' bottom line.  What happened with auto-related tariffs?  The Trump administration enacted a 25% tariff on April 3 on any vehicle not assembled in the U.S. President Donald Trump has said he also plans to place tariffs on some auto parts (including engines and transmissions), but those won't take effect until May 3.

headline: Trump Tariffs to Hit Many Auto Parts
summary: The array of automotive parts that President Trump plans to tariff is more extensive than the industry expected, raising concerns about significant cost increases for U.S.-built vehicles.  As part of Trump’s tariff announcement Wednesday, the administration published a list of auto parts that would be subject to 25% tariffs starting May 3.  The parts list is “more extensive than feared,” Bernstein financial analyst Daniel Roeska wrote in a research note following Trump’s announcement.
